pageContent:
© 2023 Bruce Monger
Global Biodiversity 
and its Current 
Decline

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Outline
1.What is Biodiversity?


2.What are the Benefits of Biodiversity


3.The Current Decline in Biodiversity


4.What is Needed to Slow the Decline?
© 2023 Bruce Monger

© 2023 Bruce Monger
“It’s not too late if we change our ways and connect the 
dots to our problems.”  — Ellie Goulding
There is still an abundance of really intense natural beauty in this world, but we 
threaten to lose much of it at global scales is we do not change our ways.


The human population has grown too large and too technologically powerful for 
us to keep moving through the world thoughtlessly. 


•
We can now stop an ice age.  


•
We are now as powerful as an astroid hitting the earth.


We need to begin to move through this world with more intelligence and care and 
see clearly how each of our actions are connected to nature (e.g., the kind of food 
we eat — the mode transportation we use — the kind of homes we build).

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Section I
1.What is Biodiversity?


2.What are the Benefits of Biodiversity?

© 2023 Bruce Monger
What is Biodiversity?

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The Biosphere
 
is a remarkably thin 
layer of interconnected organisms that 
envelops the entire earth.
 
•
The combined metabolic activity of all these 
organisms influences the 
atmosphere
, the 
geosphere
, and the 
hydrosphere
, 
both 
physically
 and 
chemically
, to form one 
environmental system.
Lets Start with the Idea of the Biosphere
•
The interaction of biotic and abiotic factors within the biosphere provide breathable air 
(i.e., 
every other breath)
, clean water 
(e.g., mangroves)
, fertile soils, bountiful seas and an equitable 
climate 
(e.g., biological carbon pump)
.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
What is Biodiversity?
Broadly Speaking
 it is the
 collective genetic knowledge
 derived from the success of evolving species 
coping with vastly varying environmental conditions that have occurred over the past 4 billion years.  
This beautiful expansive explosion of diversity that has occurred over deep geologic time.
Today 
The Collective Genetic 
Knowledge of All Living 
Creatures


550-million years ago 
Cambrian Explosion


2-billion years
, first 
Multicellular Life 


3-billion
 
years ago


Photosynthetic Bacteria


4-billion years ago 
First Life (Bacteria)
© 2023 Bruce Monger

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Species Richness
 
(the number of species in a given area)
 is a common metric of the diversity of 
life—
but it should be integrated with other metrics to fully capture biodiversity 


•
Species richness 
rarely captures key attributes 
that provide insight into the roles of biodiversity.


•
For example, keystone species like the 
starfish 
Pisaster
 
in the rocky intertidal or 
herring
 in 
coastal ocean systems 
have outsized influence/importance
 in their respective ecosystems.


Species Extinction
 provides a clear, but narrow, window on the destruction of biodiversity — it 
is the disappearance of the last member of a group that is by definition rare. 


Decline in Total Number 
of the world’s most common species can also give insight into 
biodiversity decline. 
https://www.greenfacts.org/en/biodiversity/l-3/1-define-biodiversity.htm
There are Many Measures of Biodiversity and Biodiversity’s Decline

© 2023 Bruce Monger
To date, a total of 
1.3-1.8 million species
 have been identified and described, but many more 
than this live on Earth. 


The current best estimate of total species on earth is 
8.7 million plant and animal species.
https://allyouneedisbiology.wordpress.com/2018/05/20/biodiversity-species/
https://www.nature.com/news/2011/110823/full/news.2011.498.html

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Benefits of High Biodiversity

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The Benefits of High Biodiversity
1.
Ecosystem Resilience 


2.
Ecosystem Services 


3.
Productive Ecosystems
See Also:   https://www.nature.com/scitable/knowledge/library/causes-and-consequences-of-biodiversity-declines-16132475/

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Ecosystems with high biodiversity are generally more 
resistant to disaster than those with low biodiversity. 


The America Chestnut is the Classic Example:  
•
The American
 
chestnut blight
 
killed most of the 
chestnut trees in the eastern forests of North 
America. 


•
The overall forest ecosystem survived because 
many other tree species, that were not susceptible 
to this disease, made up the overall forest 
ecosystem.
https://www.nationalgeographic.org/article/global-biodiversity/?utm_source=BibblioRCM_Row
Biodiversity and Ecosystem Resilience

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Ecosystem Services

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Biodiversity is essential to human 
wellbeing through its contribution to 
a broadly defined set of 
ecosystem 
services
.


For example, primary producers  
on land and in the ocean make the 
oxygen you breathe.  
https://www.nsf.gov/news/mmg/mmg_disp.jsp?med_id=73525&from=
Ecosystem Services

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Ecosystem Services
1.
Provision


2.
Support


3.
Culture


4.
Regulation

© 2023 Bruce Monger
According to the report 
Nature Risk Rising
 published by the World Economic Forum, 
$44 trillion
 of economic value generation – over half the world’s total GDP – is 
moderately or highly dependent on nature.
Ecosystem Services
https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2023/02/an-ecosystems-economic-value-can-now-be-measured-heres-how/

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Globally, the market value of marine 
and coastal resources and industries is 
estimated at 
$3 trillion annually
Ocean Ecosystem Services
https://www.un.org/sustainabledevelopment/oceans/

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Maintaining a High Level of Biodiversity is Foundational to Creating 
a Sustainable World That Supporting the Persistent Wellbeing of All

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development  
•
The agenda was adopted by all United Nations Member States in 2015


•
At its heart are the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) 
•
Central to these goals is a healthy/stable natural world sustained by a high 
level of biodiversity
 
https://sustainabledevelopment.un.org/rio20.html

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The 2030 Sustainable Development Goals
, and the high level of biodiversity 
that underpins many of these goals, are intended to create a socially just 
world for both current and future generations.


Consequently, maintaining a high level of biodiversity is about creating a 
socially just world!

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Section II
The Current Decline in Biodiversity

© 2023 Bruce Monger
How Bad is the Current Rate of Loss?

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services 
(IPBES): Global Assessment Report 2019 
IPBES
 — Similar to Intergovernmental Panel for Climate Change (IPCC), but for biodiversity
.


•
Charged with  assessing 
biodiversity changes over the past five decades


•
Compiled by 
145 expert authors
 from 
50 countries
 over a three-year period, with input 
from 
another 310 contributing authors.


•
The most comprehensive assessment of biodiversity ever compiled and builds on the 
landmark 
Millennium Ecosystem Assessment of 2005


The Report finds that nearly 1 million animal and plant species are threatened with 
extinction, many within decades. 
https://www.un.org/sustainabledevelopment/blog/2019/05/nature-decline-unprecedented-report/
Current Status of Global Biodiversity

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Global Assessment Report 2019 
Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES)
https://www.un.org/sustainabledevelopment/blog/2019/05/nature-decline-unprecedented-report/
The assessment report 
ranked the five direct drivers 
of change in nature:
 


1.
Changes in land and sea use 
2.
Direct exploitation of organisms  
3.
Climate change 
4.
Pollution  
5.
Invasive alien species 
Current negative trends in biodiversity and ecosystems 
will undermine progress towards 
80%
 of 
the the Sustainable Development Goals,
 related to poverty, hunger, health, water, cities, climate, 
oceans and land (SDGs 1, 2, 3, 6, 11, 13, 14 and 15). 


Loss of biodiversity is, therefore, not only an environmental issue, but it is also a developmental, 
economic, security, 
and
 social justice issue.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Between 
30 and 35 percent 
of the global extent of critical marine habitats such 
as seagrasses, mangroves and coral reefs have already been destroyed.


Without significant changes,
 more than half of the world’s marine species
 
may stand on the brink of extinction by 2100.
Facts and Figures on Marine Biodiversity
http://www.unesco.org/new/en/natural-sciences/ioc-oceans/focus-areas/rio-20-ocean/blueprint-for-the-future-we-want/marine-biodiversity/facts-and-figures-on-marine-biodiversity/
United Nations Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.abe9039
https://grist.org/climate/global-heating-risks-most-cataclysmic-extinction-of-marine-life-in-250-million-years/
In a 2022 report, global warming of 2°C will 
likely lead to species losses from the warming 
and from oxygen depletion that will be 
comparable to past mass extinction events.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The Loss of Biodiversity is a Silent Killer  
https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/nov/03/stop-biodiversity-loss-or-we-could-face-our-own-extinction-warns-un
Biodiversity is different from climate change, where people feel the impact in 
everyday life.  


With biodiversity, the change is not felt so obviously and by the time you 
feel what is happening, it may be too late.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Shifting Baseline 
Syndrome

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://www.nytimes.com/2022/09/20/opinion/ocean-environment-pollution.html
In The 1500s,  
•
Europeans exploring Nova Scotia simply dropped 
baskets in near-shore waters and hauled up large cod. 


•
Spanish sailors near Cuba saw turtles “in such vast 
numbers that they covered the sea.” 


•
Travelers noted large whales “infinite in number,” 
“impossible to be counted.” 


•
River herring once ran up rivers from the sea to spawn 
in quantities that seemed “unbelievable, indeed, 
indescribable, as also incomprehensible.”

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Section III
What is Needed to Slow the Decline?

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1. We cannot solve the threats of human-induced 
climate change
 and loss of 
biodiversity
 
in isolation. 


2.
We
 still have time
 – though very limited – to turn things around.  It requires massive 
changes, from 
removing harmful subsidies 
that lead to the destruction of nature to 
enacting laws that encourage the protection
 of nature and 
rethinking the definition 
of a rewarding life. 
3. We need to
 redirect positive government subsidies
 towards more sustainable and 
regenerative farming practices.
  
4. The world needs to recognize that loss of biodiversity and human-induced climate 
change are 
not only an environmental issue, but also a moral issue. 
Robert Watson: Opinion
Chair of IPBES, and former Chair of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC)
https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2019/may/06/biodiversity-climate-change-mass-extinctions

© 2023 Bruce Monger
If We
 Don’t Change Our 
Ways...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Hopeful Signs

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Protecting nature and saving species is all about securing the land and 
water that plants and animals need to survive.  
 
 
Protecting 
half of the planet (both land and ocean) by 2050
, with an interim target 
of 
30% by 2030
, is the only way to meet the Paris climate targets and achieve the 
UN’s Sustainable Development Goals for the world.


Currently, the world only safeguards 
17%
 of terrestrial areas and 
8%
 of marine areas, 
and many of these areas are not effectively managed or well-placed to achieve 
biodiversity outcomes.
https://www.nationalgeographic.com/environment/2019/05/ipbes-un-biodiversity-report-warns-one-million-species-at-risk/
The Scale of What is Needed to Protect Biodiversity 
on Land and Ocean
https://science.sciencemag.org/content/361/6407/1051

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Protecting 
30 percent of U.S. lands and ocean by 2030 
is among the most ambitious of the administration’s 
overall environmental agenda.


Natural landscapes and seascapes are seen as 
important natural carbon sinks, pulling CO
2
 from the 
atmosphere and storing it as organic carbon in soil, 
grasses, shrubs, and trees, coral reefs, sea grasses, and 
ocean floor sediments.
https://yaleclimateconnections.org/2021/03/details-behind-bidens-30-by-30-u-s-lands-and-oceans-climate-goal/
In 2021 the Biden Administration Pledged to 
Conserve 30% of Land and Ocean by 2030

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The Convention on 
Biological Diversity (CBD)
Signed by 150 government leaders at the 
1992 Rio Earth Summit
. 
The overarching goal is for people “to live in harmony with nature” by 2050. 


It has 3 main objectives:
 


1. The conservation of biological diversity


2. The sustainable use of the components of biological diversity


3.
The fair and equitable sharing of the benefits arising out of the 
utilization of genetic resources
https://www.cbd.int/convention/

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://www.carbonbrief.org/cop15-key-outcomes-agreed-at-the-un-biodiversity-conference-in-montreal/
COP-15
 was held in Kunming, China in October 2021 and Montreal, Canada in 
December 2022


The
 
Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework 
was reached on 


19 December 2022 at the COP-15 meeting.


Among the Framework’s key elements are 4 goals for 2050 and 23 targets for 2030.
 

It included the target to conserve
 30% of the world’s land and 30% of the ocean 
by 2030
.


A second “30 by 30” target was also made with developed countries agreeing to 
mobilize 
$30bn for developing countries by 2030
.
The Conference of the Parties (COP) Governs the Convention 
on Biological Diversity (CBD).
 
https://www.cbd.int/gbf/

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/inc3.24
As part of the 
Kunming
‐
Montreal Global Biodiversity 
Framework
, the signatory nations aim to protect 30% 
of the planet by 2030. 


However, many signatory nations have, in the past, 
prioritized quantity (e.g., area) over quality (e.g., 
important areas for high biodiversity)
  
It is critical that nations focus on protecting those 
terrestrial, inland waters and marine areas 
that have the 
best chance of halting and reversing biodiversity loss
. 
Quantity versus Quality
https://www.oneearth.org/guide-to-expanding-protected-and-conserved-areas-under-the-un-global-biodiversity-framework/

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://www.nwf.org/Our-Work/Wildlife-Conservation/Policy/Recovering-Americas-Wildlife-Act
https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2022/08/09/recovering-america-wildlife-act-conservation-law/
Passed the House  (H.R.2773) 
Recovering America’s Wildlife Act 2022
Would have provided nearly $1.4 billion 
annually 
to protect vulnerable wildlife and help 
them recover.


The Senate version (S.2372)
 had more than 
40 cosponsors, with strong support from both 
parties.
https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/senate-bill/2372

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Recovering America’s Wildlife Act
The 2022 bill failed despite strong bipartisan 
support.  


Politicians could not come to an agreement 
on a funding mechanism.” 
Update 2023:
 Senators Martin Heinrich (D-
New Mexico) and Thom Tillis (R-North 
Carolina) reintroduced RAWA into the U.S. 
Senate on 
March 31, 2023
. 


The new bill’s backers say they will seek a 
funding mechanism that can generate enough 
bipartisan support to ultimately pass the bill in 
both houses of Congress.
https://www.allaboutbirds.org/news/recovering-americas-wildlife-act-fails-in-final-days-of-117th-congress/#

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The Scale of What is Needed to 
Protect Biodiversity in the Ocean
https://www.pewtrusts.org/trust/archive/summer-2021/can-we-protect-the-ocean-by-2030
 
Optional Reading...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
What Can An Individual Do To
 Help?
https://www.theguardian.com/news/2018/mar/12/what-is-biodiversity-and-why-does-it-matter-to-us
1.
VOTE! VOTE! VOTE!   
2.
Currently, most wildlife is destroyed by land being cleared for cattle, 
soy, palm oil, timber and leather. 
•
Most of us consume these products every day, with palm oil being 
found in many foods and toiletries. 


•
Choosing only sustainable options helps, as does eating less meat, 
particularly beef, which has an outsized environmental 
hoofprint
.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Iliana Paleva
, who was a student 
in a past oceanography class, 
started a club called 
"The Impact 
Project"
 to highlight Cornell 
students who 
act
 on their 
sustainability beliefs.  


Elizabeth Couse ’19
 was chosen 
to be the student spotlight.  The 
following video shows her personal 
story and her commitment to the 
environment.  


The theme is how we need to be 
conscious of our choices, with a 
slight focus on plastic pollution and 
our oceans.
 
An Example of a Cornell Undergraduate 
Acting
 on Her Understanding of the 
Social Justice of Living Sustainably...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
•
Three-quarters of the land-based environment and about 66% of the marine environment have been significantly altered by human 
actions. On average these trends have been less severe or avoided in areas held or managed by Indigenous Peoples and Local 
Communities.


•
More than a third of the world’s land surface and nearly 75% of freshwater resources are now devoted to crop or livestock production.


•
The value of agricultural crop production has increased by about 300% since 1970, raw timber harvest has risen by 45% and 
approximately 60 billion tons of renewable and nonrenewable resources are now extracted globally every year – having nearly doubled 
since 1980.


•
Land degradation has reduced the productivity of 23% of the global land surface, up to US$577 billion in annual global crops are at risk 
from pollinator loss and 100-300 million people are at increased risk of floods and hurricanes because of loss of coastal habitats and 
protection.


•
In 2015, 33% of marine fish stocks were being harvested at unsustainable levels; 60% were maximally sustainably fished, with just 7% 
harvested at levels lower than what can be sustainably fished.


•
Urban areas have more than doubled since 1992.


•
Plastic pollution has increased tenfold since 1980, 300-400 million tons of heavy metals, solvents, toxic sludge and other wastes from 
industrial facilities are dumped annually into the world’s waters, and fertilizers entering coastal ecosystems have produced more than 
400 ocean ‘dead zones’, totaling more than 245,000 km2 (591-595) – a combined area greater than that of the United Kingdom.

•
Negative trends in nature will continue to 2050 and beyond in all of the policy scenarios explored in the Report, except those that 
include transformative change – due to the projected impacts of increasing land-use change, exploitation of organisms and climate 
change, although with significant differences between regions.
Appendix: Other notable findings of the IPBES Report*
https://www.un.org/sustainabledevelopment/blog/2019/05/nature-decline-unprecedented-report/
